revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Grand Croix of the Ordre national du Mérite to [[:Category:Grand Cross of the National Order of Merit (France)]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 April 30]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox person/Wikidata | fetchwikidata=ALL}} '''Jacqueline Auriol''' (5 November 1917, [[Challans]], [[Vendée]] – 11 February 2000, [[Paris]]) was a [[France|French]] [[aviator]] who set several world speed records.<ref>{{cite news | title=Jacqueline Auriol, Top French Test Pilot, 82 | first=Douglas | last=Martin | newspaper=The New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/17/world/jacqueline-auriol-top-french-test-pilot-82.html | date=February 17, 2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | first=Patricia | last=Trenner | journal=Air & Space Magazine | title=10 Great Pilots | publisher=Smithsonian Institution | url=http://www.airspacemag.com/history-of-flight/cit-trenner.html?c=y&page=6 | date=March 1, 2003}}</ref>
==Biography== [[Image:Auriollivetofly.jpg|thumb|''I Live to Fly'' - Auriol's autobiography]] Born as '''Jacqueline Marie-Thérèse Suzanne Douet''' in [[Challans]], [[Vendée]], the daughter of a wealthy [[shipbuilder]], she graduated from the [[University of Nantes]] then she studied art at the [[École du Louvre]] in [[Paris]].
In 1938, she married Paul Auriol, son of [[Vincent Auriol]] (who would later become [[President of France]]). During World War II, Jacqueline Auriol, worked against the [[German occupation of France during World War II|German occupation of France]] by helping the [[French Resistance]].
She took up flying in 1946, got her pilot's license in 1948 and became an accomplished stunt flier and test pilot. Jacqueline was severely injured in a crash of a [[SCAN 30]] in which she was a passenger in 1949—many of the bones in her face were broken—and spent nearly three years in hospitals undergoing 33 reconstructive operations. To occupy her mind she studied algebra, trigonometry, aerodynamics, and other subjects necessary to obtain advanced pilot certification.
She earned a military [[pilot license]] in 1950 then qualified as one of the first female [[test pilots]]. She was among the first women to break the [[sound barrier]] and set five world speed records in the 1950s and 1960s.
On four occasions she was awarded the [[Harmon Trophy|Harmon International Trophy]] by an American president in recognition of her aviation exploits. She once explained her passion for flying by saying: "I feel so happy when I'm flying. Perhaps it is the feeling of power, the pleasure of dominating a machine as beautiful as a [[Thoroughbred]] horse. Mingled with these basic joys is another less primitive feeling, that of a mission accomplished. Each time I set foot on an airfield, I sense with fresh excitement that this is where I belong."
Her life story was told in her 1970 autobiography ''I Live to Fly'' published in the [[French language|French]] and [[English language]]s.
Jacqueline and her husband divorced in 1967 and remarried in 1987. They had two sons together. In 1983 she became a founding member of the French ''[[Académie de l'air et de l'espace]]''.
==Records== Jacqueline Auriol set the following speed records:<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.fai.org/records|title=FAI Records|last=|first=|date=|website=www.fai.org|language=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-02}} Search for "Jacqueline Auriol" in the "Person, Record, Year, ID..?" field under "Record Search".</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/index.html|title=Aviation History - Browse the History of Flight from 1909|website=www.flightglobal.com|access-date=2017-04-02}}</ref>
*'''12 May 1951''' - Auriol set a ''[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]''- (FAI-) ratified average speed of {{Convert|818.18|km/h|mph|abbr=on|sigfig=5}}<ref name=":0" /> flying a British-made [[de Havilland Vampire|Vampire]] over a 100-km (62.1-mile) closed circuit in France from [[Istres]], outside [[Marseilles]], to [[Avignon]] and back to claim the women's world air speed record from its previous holder, [[Jacqueline Cochran]] of the [[United States]]. *'''21 December 1952''' - Flying a [[SNCASE|Sud-Est]] Mistral (a French-built development of the Vampire with a [[Rolls Royce Nene|Hispano-Suiza Nene]] engine), Auriol broke her own 1951 world speed record over a 100-km (62.1-mile) closed circuit by flying at {{Convert|855.92|km/h|mph|abbr=on|sigfig=5}}.<ref name=":0" /> The new record was set over the same 100-km (62.1-mile) closed course as in 1951, from Istres to Avignon and back. *'''31 May 1955''' - Flying a [[Dassault Mystère IV|Mystère IVN]], Auriol broke the previous women's speed record over a 15/25-km (9.3/15.5-mile) straight course previously held by Jacqueline Cochrane with an FAI-ratified speed of {{Convert|1151|km/h|mph|abbr=on|sigfig=4}}.<ref name=":0" /> *'''22 Jun 1962''' - Flying a [[Dassault Mirage IIIC]], Auriol achieved an FAI-ratified average speed of {{Convert|1850.2|km/h|mph|abbr=on|sigfig=5}}<ref name=":0" /> over the 100-km (62.1-mile) closed circuit at Istres, to reclaim the women's world air speed record in that category from Jacqueline Cochran. *'''14 Jun 1963''' - Flying a [[Dassault Mirage III#Mirage IIIR|Dassault Mirage IIIR]], Auriol achieved an FAI-ratified average speed of {{Convert|2,038.70|km/h|mph|abbr=on|sigfig=6}}<ref name=":0" /> over a 100-km (62.1-mile) closed circuit at Istres. It was her final attempt to break the women's air speed record over that distance, and she broke a record Jacqueline Cochran had set over the distance in May 1963.
On 1 June 1964, Cochran broke Auriol′s June 1963 record, achieving an FAI-ratified average speed of {{Convert|2097.27|km/h|mph|abbr=on|sigfig=6}}<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.fai.org/records|title=FAI Records|last=|first=|date=|website=www.fai.org|language=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-02}} Search for "Jacqueline Cochran" in the "Person, Record, Year, ID..?" field under "Record Search".</ref> over a 100-km (62.1-mile) closed circuit in a [[Lockheed F-104 Starfighter|Lockheed F-104G Starfighter]].
==Honours== * She was awarded four [[Harmon Trophy|Harmon Trophies]] in 1951, 1952, 1955 and 1956. * She was made ''Grand officier'' (Grand officer) of the [[Légion d'honneur]]. * She was made ''grand-croix'' (Grand cross) of the [[Ordre national du Mérite]] in 1997.<ref>{{Citation|title=ORDRE NATIONAL DU MERITE Décret du 14 mai 1997 portant élévation à la dignité de grand'croix et de grand officier|url=https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?cidTexte=JORFTEXT000000749083|language=French|accessdate=2017-04-02}}</ref> * Honored as an [[Gathering of Eagles Program|Eagle]] in 1992.<ref> [http://www.au.af.mil/au/goe/eagle_bios/1992/auriol_1992.asp Gathering of Eagles Program]</ref> *On 23 June 2003, France issued a [[Euro sign|€]]4.00 postage stamp in her honor.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.wnsstamps.ch/en/stamps/FR043.03 | title=FR043.03 | work=Universal Postal Union | accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref>
==Sources== * ''I Live to Fly'' - Jacqueline Auriol. (1970) [[E.P. Dutton|E.P. Dutton & Co.]]: New York; {{ISBN|0-525-13076-4}}
==See also== *[[Jacqueline Cochran]]
==References== {{reflist}}
